page.title: 17HISTORY OF ALKHAM CHURCH.
page.content: During the Danish invasion a small temple was constructed and following the Norman Conquest a small church with nave and chancel was built on the present site. The 13th century was a period of rebuilding and improvement in the Early English style, a north chapel was added.During the Middle Ages and following the Reformation the church fell into disrepair.The holding of several benefices by one person resulted in much absenteeism and the church remained locked for months at a time.Later the north chapel was boarded up and a school established in the chancel.Considerable restoration took place during the Victorian era, the north chapel was re-roofed and the gables reglazed.The bell tower was partly rebuilt.The church was finally restored in 1959 when the north chapel was re-opened with a new altar.
